#### Model Backend In the **Model Backend** group, choose your Checkpoint, VAE, Upscale Model as well as ControlNet Model and the Pre-processor Model.
If you're using a v-prediction model, make sure to enable "Is V-Pred Model". --- #### LoRA's / Detection Models In the second row select the LoRA's of your choice, select your detection models for the body parts and fill out the prompts for specific body parts(or leave as is) and select Detailer LoRA's for specific body-parts if you have any. --- #### Sampler Settings Change the sampler settings according to your wishes or leave as is. You can change the Resolution more accurately by double clicking the height and width values and entering a value manually. The default settings are my personal preferences.
The settings for CFG, steps, scheduler & sampler also apply to all of the detailers to keep a consistent setting for all parts of the generation.
At the bottom of the "Sampler settings"-Group you can find three sliders that are exclusively for ControlNet. If you do not know what they do you should leave them as is, but they can be used to control the influence of the ControlNet over your final result. --- #### Function Control In the "Function Control"-Group you can select which Detailers to run, what manual body part prompts to use and what detailer LoRA's to activate. Here you can also control if you want to use a start and/or quality prompt, if you'd like to use ControlNet and/or the Pre-Processor to either imitate a pose from a pose image or a reference image and if you want to use the IPAdapter to imitate an image's style and/or composition. --- #### ControlNet You can either provide a full image in the "Pre-Processing" image selector or a ControlNet pose image in the "Load ControlNet Pose" image selector below.
The ControlNet image has to match the ControlNet model in the node inside of the "Model Backend"-Group.
If you want to imitate the pose of an image and have selected a image in the "Pre-Processing"-Node inside the "ControlNet"-Group you have to enable the "Use Pre-Processor"-Node in the "Process Control"-Group.
After selecting a pre-processing model at the bottom of the "Model Backend"-Group you can see a preview of the generated/used next to the ControlNet switches in the "Process Control"-Group. You can find an in-depth guide about what ControlNet is, what it does and how each model works in [this](https://stable-diffusion-art.com/controlnet/) guide. (It's for A1111WebUI but you'll understand) --- #### IPAdapter IPAdapter let's you copy the style of an image simply by providing an IPAdapter Model & a Clip Model.
It basically works as a 1-Image-LoRA that injects itself into the Model and applies the style of the image like a LoRA. The composition part works similar to ControlNet where the general composition is being copied by the image.
You can select an image for the style and an image for the composition individually in the "IPAdapter (Optional)"-Group and then set the strength of their influence in the "Sampler Settings"-Group.
In general if you're just trying to copy the style of one image and the position of another image i'd recommend using ControlNet for the pose and IPAdapter for the style.

Be aware that you still have to prompt correctly with IPAdapter, otherwise the concept or pose of the input image will heavily influence the final image(if you're not using ControlNet or a Composition image). --- #### Prompts Consists of start quality prompts, positive prompt, end quality prompts and negative prompts. If you're like me and want to use the same quality tags across multiple different prompts you can activate/deactivate the quality prompts in the "Process Control"-Group. Comma automatically gets appended to the end of the quality prompt and the positive prompt. To see what your full prompt looks like you can check the "Prompt preview"-Node inside the "Debug"-Group underneath the image preview. --- `To the left are my recommended detection models as well as Detailer LoRA's for some of them that i use regularly. At the bottom you can find collections of Poses for ControlNet.`

To use ControlNet you first have to download the ControlNet Models for NoobAI.
These models work for Eps, VPred and even Illustrious models.
So you don't need to use a NoobAI model if you prefer using Illustrious Checkpoints.

You can find these Models [here](https://civitai.com/models/929685 ).
The OpenPose model [here](https://huggingface.co/Laxhar/noob_openpose/tree/main).
Or all of them in their huggingface collection [here](https://huggingface.co/collections/Laxhar/noobai-sdxl-controlnet-67342fca03831b10647d7910). ### Save these in your /models/controlnet folder

Please leave feedback or questions [here](https://civitai.com/models/1297813/comfyui-detaileradetailer-all-in-one-illustrious-pony-sdxl).
Thank you for using my Workflow!

## Detailer Tips & Usage Guide

### Prompt Behavior
- If **body-part specific prompts** are **disabled**, the detailer uses the **standard positive/negative prompts**.
- Detectors and checkpoints usually infer the content well through denoising.
- However, **writing specific prompts** for body parts results in **better and more accurate** generations.
- To enhance further, use a **Detailer LoRA** (see recommended ones to the left).
- If no specific LoRA exists, use a **general Detailer** (EPS or V-Pred) and prompt what you want shown.

> By default, **negative prompts** are shared with the main image generation.  
> To use a custom one, connect a new **Text Prompt Node** in the  
> `"Backend - Detailer Preparation"` group.

---

### Debug Preview

- After generation, check the **debug area** for one node per detected body part.
- Click the rectangle next to a node's name to view the **mask**.
- If the preview:
  - shows the **full image** → the detailer was **inactive**.
  - is **black** → the model **found no match**.

> If no match is found, try changing the detection model  
> or tweaking the **Detailer parameters** below.

---

## Key Detailer Parameters

- **`bbox_crop_factor`**: Controls how much context around the area is used.
  - `1.0` = tight crop, `3.0` = broader context.
  - Too low = lacks context; too high = loses detail.
  - Optimal range: **1.0–3.0**.

- **`denoise`**: Determines how much of the original is changed.
  - `0.5` = balanced, `1.0` = full replacement.
  - Low to mid-range is ideal to retain original form while enhancing detail.

- **Positive Prompt Node**:  
  Use optional body-part positive prompts in the "Detailer prompts"-Group.  
  Use **body-part specific LoRA’s** for best results.

- **Matching Parts**:  
  Use a **detection model** that recognized a pair of eyes, nipples, etc., to ensure consistency.

- **Preserve Original Details**:
  - Lower **CFG** or **denoise** to retain color/shape (e.g., iris).
### Civitai has a large amount of available poses collections you can browse through the Poses filter [here](https://civitai.com/search/models?modelType=Poses&sortBy=models_v9).

To use the IPAdapter you first have to download the IPAdapter Model for NoobAI.
This models work for Eps, VPred and Illustrious models.
You can find the Model [here](https://civitai.com/models/1000401?modelVersionId=1121145 ). ### Save this in your /models/ipadapter folder You also need a compatible Clip-vision Model which you can either find [here](https://huggingface.co/axssel/IPAdapter_ClipVision_models/blob/main/CLIP-ViT-bigG-14-laion2B-39B-b160k.safetensors) or through the Comfy Model Manager by searching for "CLIP-ViT-bigG-14-laion2B". ### Save this in your /models/clip_vision folder

#### Debug Section

You can open the previews above by clicking the rectangle symbol next to the name.
They show the improved part by the detailer.

If the whole image is in the preview it means that the Detailer is disabled, no changes have been made.

If the preview is a black rectangle it means the Ultralytics detection model has not found any matches.

You might choose a different detection model or change settings in the detailer.
(See "Improve further" on the left)

The prompt preview to the left side of this note shows you the combination of positive prompts in your workflow.
